In this section, we evaluate the benefits of combining our NFA𝒩subscriptNFA𝒩\textsc{NFA}_{\mathcal{N}}NFA start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT detection head with the different SSL initialization, namely DINO, ReSim and SparK. The results obtained on SIRST and IRSTD-850 datasets are presented in Table I. They have been averaged over three distinct training sessions.
First, we can notice that integrating an a contrario criterion into the training loop of YOLO-R50 leads to more robust and precise results as shown by the AP metric. Moreover, YOLO-R50+NFA𝒩subscriptNFA𝒩\textsc{NFA}_{\mathcal{N}}NFA start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT significantly improves the F1 score on the challenging IRSTD-850 dataset (+4.7%percent4.7+4.7\%+ 4.7 %).
Second, combining SSL with YOLO-R50+NFA𝒩subscriptNFA𝒩\textsc{NFA}_{\mathcal{N}}NFA start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT further improves the results. More specifically, YOLO-R50+NFA𝒩subscriptNFA𝒩\textsc{NFA}_{\mathcal{N}}NFA start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT initialized with ReSim weights achieves more than 99%percent9999\%99 % of F1 score, outperforming all other methods by a wide margin. It is worth noting that instance discrimination methods, whether local or global, appear to be more effective for IRSTD than MIM methods. This might seem counter-intuitive, as one would expect that extracting local features would be more beneficial for detecting small objects. However, this can be explained by the fact that higher-level feature extraction complements the locality already introduced by the convolutional layers. Additionally, the performance of MIM methods, which are more sensitive to image statistics due to their strong bias towards local details [33], may be limited by the domain gap between RGB training domain for the backbone layers, then frozen and IR (application domain).

For this section, we focus on the most promising method according to Table I, namely YOLO-R50+NFA𝒩subscriptNFA𝒩\textsc{NFA}_{\mathcal{N}}NFA start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with ReSim initialization. We aim to evaluate it under more challenging conditions, namely 25252525-shot training on SIRST. Specifically, we compare YOLO-R50+NFA𝒩subscriptNFA𝒩\textsc{NFA}_{\mathcal{N}}NFA start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (using either randomly initialized weights or ReSim initialization) with several baselines: 1) SOTA segmentation networks for IRSTD and 2) YOLO baselines (some with ReSim initialization). The results, averaged over three distinct training sessions, are presented on Table II.

In the previous sections, we have seen that both a contrario and self-supervised paradigms have led to impressive results for IRSTD. Specifically, combining both paradigms greatly improves the YOLO baselines, especially in a frugal context, where the SOTA segmentation methods are outperformed by a wide margin.
In this section, we compare our best candidate method, namely YOLO-R50+NFA𝒩subscriptNFA𝒩\textsc{NFA}_{\mathcal{N}}NFA start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT initialized with ReSim weights, to SOTA segmentation baselines in a data-sufficient context on SIRST and IRSTD-85 datasets. The results, shown in Table III, indicate that our approach sets new SOTA results on the SIRST dataset: YOLO-R50 + NFA𝒩subscriptNFA𝒩\textsc{NFA}_{\mathcal{N}}NFA start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT initialized with ReSim weights outperforms DNANet and DNIM+NFA by a wide margin, achieving over 99%percent9999\%99 % F1 score. This is particularly noteworthy because detection networks typically struggle with small objects compared to segmentation networks.
